title: Gravitational Waves Explained
text:
What Are Gravitational Waves?



Predicted in 1916 by Albert Einstein
fabric of spacetime (4D)
Mass and energy curve spacetime \(\to\) gravity





Image of gravitational wave (simulation) — Courtesy Caltech/MIT/LIGO Laboratory (LIGO Laboratory 2015)

title: Gravitational Waves Explained
text:
Why Gravitational Waves Matter

Traditional astronomy relies on electromagnetic radiation
Light can be: Absorbed, Scattered, Blocked by dust or gas
Gravitational waves:

Interact extremely weakly with matter
Travel largely unimpeded

Enable observation of:

Black hole mergers
Otherwise inaccessible regions

How do we measure GW

A Simplified Schematic diagram of a LIGO (Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory) detector (Commons 2020)

title: Gravitational Waves Explained
text:
The Chirp Signal: Blackhole merger



Detected on September 14, 2015
36 and 29 solar masses
\(\approx 1.3 \textrm{B ly}\) away
2017 Nobel Prize in Physics
Increasing frequency, amplitude
Converted to sound:

sound like a bird chirp






First measurement: GW150914 (Commons 2025)

title: Gravitational Waves Explained
text:
Sensitivity of LIGO

Measures changes:

10,000 \(\times\) smaller than a proton’s diameter (\(10^{-20} m\))

Equivalent to:

Measuring distance to nearest star (\(4.2\) ly) w/ precision smaller than a human hair

Glitches

Earthquakes, Traffic vibrations, Thermal vibrations, Quantum laser noise

title: Gravitational Waves Explained
text:
Glitch Classification Challenge



Many glitch sources remain unknown
Some closely resemble real signals
Distinguishing signal vs noise is a classification problem





Different classes of glitches in Gravity Spy Glanzer et al. (2023)

title: Gravitational Waves Explained
text:
Machine Learning & Classification
Methods used include:

Random forest classifiers Shah et al. (2023)
Image-based classifiers Alvarez-Lopez et al. (2023)
Cross-correlation between detectors

LIGO (United States), Virgo (Europe), KAGRA (Japan)


True gravitational waves: - Consistent signal in multiple detectors

title: Gravitational Waves Explained
text:
Citizen Science: Gravity Spy

Crowd-sourced glitch classification
Combines:

Human pattern recognition
Machine learning

Improves detection reliability and efficiency

title: Gravitational Waves Explained
text:
Key Takeaways

Gravitational waves open a new window on the universe
LIGO measures extraordinarily tiny spacetime distortions
Noise makes detection a major classification challenge
Machine learning and citizen science are essential tools
